newsitem.title: UK: US Treasuries firm in London, short end lags.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries firm in London, short end lags.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries started the week on a firm note on Monday, although the short end lagged somewhat ahead of two- and five-year auctions this week, dealers and analysts said.
"Overall the market has held a good bid. The technical tone has improved going into this week," said a dealer at a Japanese bank in London.

The bellwether 30-year long bond was quoted at 99-18 at 0912 GMT, up from 99-14/15 at the Tokyo finish and 99-12/13 at Friday's close in New York. But the short end underperformed, with the two- to 30-year spread shrinking slightly.
The spread was at 93 basis points down from highs around 96 to 97 last week.

The Treasury is scheduled to auction $18.25 billion of two-year notes on Tuesday and $12.5 billion of five-year paper on Wednesday. Graham McDevitt, senior analyst at Paribas Capital Markets in London, said that the market's previous fears of a U.S. interest rate increase were proving overdone so ultimately the curve could steepen further after the temporary short end underperformance.
"We've been pushing the theme of curve steepness for some time. If the (two-30 spread) could break above 100 it could be heading towards the 130 area," he said.
He said the Eurodollar strip had built up too gloomy a view on U.S. interest rates and as that unwound it would support curve steepening.
Further out, the market was beginning to contemplate not only a victory for President Clinton in the November elections but also a possible Democratic sweep, analysts said.
"As we go into the election, with Clinton still looking to be doing very well, the market's unlikely to sustain a break higher," McDevitt said.
The market's vulnerability is based on the idea that a mandate to boost spending programmes could undermine the fiscal progress that has been made in the U.S., analysts said.
In automated trade, the December U.S. T-bond was at 111-12, up from 111-09 at the prior close in Chicago.
